journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part C: Journal of Mechanical Engineering Science

title-group.article-title: Numerical study of the effect of the yield drop phenomenon on the deformation behaviour of a Taylor projectile

article-meta.aff: School of Mechanical Engineering, University of Leeds, UK

author-notes.corresp: D C Barton, School of Mechanical Engineering, University of Leeds, Leeds LS2 9JT, UK. Email: d.c.barton@leeds.ac.uk

article-meta.issue-title: Includes a special section on Parametric Excitation: Applications in science and engineering

abstract.p: This article deals with the effects of parameters relating to the yield drop phenomenon on the deformation of Taylor projectiles. The numerical modelling approach performed using LS-DYNA was validated by considering a solid cylindrical projectile made of AA7010 aluminium alloy impacted against a massive, rigid target as described in the literature. Both the projectile and target were modelled using three-dimensional brick elements. A popular strain rate and temperature-dependent constitutive relation known as the Johnson–Cook model was used to represent the alloy projectile material behaviour, whilst the target plate was assumed to be rigid. A generally good agreement between test and numerical results was found. A steel projectile was then considered using a simple piecewise linear plasticity model which has provision for introducing the yield drop effect and in which temperature effects were ignored. The impact velocities varied from 200 to 1000 m/s. Significant influence of the yield drop on the deformation behaviour of the projectile at low impact velocities was found. However, the effect was far less significant at higher impact velocities (>400 m/s).

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The Taylor projectile impact test was initially developed for assessing the high-strain rate dynamic compressive yield stress of materials.1,2 Taylor’s original approach consists of firing a cylindrical solid projectile against a massive, rigid target. The front part of this projectile expands radially or 'mushrooms'; however, the rear part of the projectile is left undeformed. By considering the deformed and undeformed profiles of the Taylor projectile and the initial impact velocity, a minimum value for dynamic yield stress can be determined.2

Recently, one of the main purposes of the Taylor’s test has been to validate the constitutive relations used in explicit finite element solvers such as LS-DYNA and ABAQUS/Explicit by comparing the predicted post-impact deformation behaviour of the Taylor projectile with experiment. Forde et al.3 outlined the use of symmetric Taylor impact tests for the validation of constitutive models of copper and Rolled Homogeneous Armour steel. They also made predictions of rod/projectile deformation profiles using the Armstrong–Zerilli constitutive model within a Lagrangian finite element code and found excellent correlation between test and computed results for both materials. Teng et al.4 studied the Taylor impact test through numerical simulations using ABAQUS/Explicit for two different materials, 2024-T351 aluminium alloy and Weldox E460 steel. The impact velocities varied from 240 to 600 m/s and the Johnson–Cook material model was used to describe the stress–strain data of the test materials. The investigators observed a number of cracks in the material due to circumferential tensile stress wave propagation.4 Taylor testing of tungsten alloy was considered using both experimental and numerical approaches by Couque and Cazenave.5 The effect of projectile size was studied and it was found that an increase in specimen length implies an increase in final-to-initial diameter ratios associated with an increase of the effective plastic strain at the impact face.

In a very different field from that of Taylor impact testing, simulations of chip formation during high-speed machining of metals, such as carbon steels have indicated the significant influence of the inclusion of an upper yield point in the description of initial yielding. Without such inclusion, it has been found that the cutting and thrust forces and chip thickness ratio predicted by simulations do not simultaneously agree with experimental results.6–10 This statement applies to machining at typical cutting speeds used in industry. Such speeds, typically 100 to 500 m/min, lead to strain rates in the chip formation zone in the range 103 to 104 s−1 and to a time duration of loading of the material, as it approaches the deformation zone of the order of 10−4 s. As long ago as the 1960s, it was suggested that such short loading times affect the material deformation characteristics. It was noted that speeds >100 m/min resulted in very different chip formation characteristics than speeds <0.5 m/min (when loading times are >10−2 s).11 The range of times from >10−2 to <10−4 s is the range over which the yield delay and yield point phenomena become significant.12,13

These short time durations and high-strain rates are also typical of deformations during the Taylor test, and it is interesting to investigate whether the yield drop phenomenon affects the deformation of such projectiles. Hence, this article studies the effects of parameters relating to the yield drop phenomenon on the deformation of steel projectiles when fired against a rigid target. The numerical modelling approach was first validated by considering a solid cylindrical projectile made of AA7010 alloy impacted against a massive, rigid target and a comparison was made between test data and numerical results. A mild steel projectile was then considered using a simple piecewise linear plasticity model which has provision for introducing the yield drop effect and in which temperature effects were ignored. Several different material models and a range of impact velocities between 200 and 1000 m/s were considered.

sec.title: Numerical validation of Taylor projectile impact
sec.p:
The finite element model of the Taylor impact test consisting of an AA7010 aluminium alloy projectile and a rigid steel target is shown in Figure 1. The length and diameter of the projectile are 46.5 and 9.30 mm, respectively, giving a length-to-diameter ratio (l/d) of 5 in line with the experiments described in the study of Vili Panov.1 An explicit finite element solver, LS-DYNA,14 was used for all simulations. Both projectile and target plate were modelled using three-dimensional solid elements. A general contact interface algorithm was defined between the projectile and the target plate and frictional effects at the interface were also considered. The values assumed for the static and dynamic frictional coefficients were 0.3 and 0.1, respectively. A popular strain rate and temperature-dependent model (i.e. Johnson–Cook material model) available in LS-DYNA was used to represent the stress–strain data of the projectile alloy material as defined in the following section. The target plate material was assumed to be rigid. Figure 1.
Finite element model of the geometry of Taylor projectile and target plate.

sec.title: Johnson–Cook material model
sec.p: The Johnson–Cook model is a strain rate and temperature-dependent viscoplastic model. This model is suitable for problems where the strain rates vary over a large range, and temperature change due to plastic dissipation may cause thermal softening. The Johnson–Cook model represents the current material flow stress σY with an equation of the following form14 (1) where ɛp is the effective plastic strain, ɛ·* the normalised effective plastic strain rate and A (quasi-static yield stress), B (strain hardening coefficient), C (strain rate hardening coefficient), n (work hardening exponent) and m(temperature softening index) the constants for a given material.

The homogeneous temperature, T * in equation (1), is defined as follows (2) where T is the current material temperature, Tref a reference (usually room) temperature and Tmelt the melting temperature of the material. The model values required for the AA7010 alloy were obtained from the study of Vili Panov1 and are listed in Table 1. Table 1.
Johnson–Cook strain rate parameters of AA7010 alloy from the study of Vili Panov.1
Parameter Parameter description Nominal value
G Shear modulus 26 GPa
A Yield stress 547 MPa
B Strain hardening coefficient 602 MPa
C Strain rate hardening coefficient 0.0022
n Work hardening exponent 0.65
m Temperature softening index 1.03
Tref Reference temperature 293 K
Tmelt Melting temperature 893 K
ɛ·0 Reference strain rate 6.4 s−1
pcut Pressure cut-off (failure stress) 1.3 GPa
Cp Specific heat 896 J/kg-K

sec.title: Effect of element size on deformation of AA7010 alloy projectiles
sec.p:
The objective of this section is to determine a suitable element size which will yield reliable results. With this aim in mind, the Taylor projectile was meshed using solid element sizes of 1 × 1 × 1.2 mm3, 1 × 2 × 1.2 mm3, 1 × 3 × 1.2 mm3 and 1 × 4 × 1.2 mm3, as shown in Figure 2. For this comparison, an impact velocity of 200 m/s was assumed as per the study of Vili Panov.1 The smallest time step required for these analyses based on the minimum element dimension is 1.22 × 10−8 s. Figure 2.
FE models of projectile meshed using different element sizes: (a) 1 × 1 × 1.2 mm3, (b) 1 × 2 × 1.2 mm3, (c) 1 × 3 × 1.2 mm3 and (d) 1 × 4 × 1.2 mm3.

The ratio of final to original diameters of projectiles with distance from the impact end for the various mesh densities is shown in Figure 3. It can be seen that significant differences exist between the results for the various mesh densities with the finer mesh densities expected to give the more reliable results. However, there was little difference in the deformed profiles between the 1 × 1 × 1.2 mm3 and 1 × 2 × 1.2 mm3 element sizes, indicating that convergence of the numerical solution had been achieved. Therefore, the 1 × 2 × 1.2 mm3 element size was considered suitable for the subsequent analyses due to its computational efficiency. Figure 3.
Ratio of final to original diameters of projectiles for varying element sizes.

The post-test and post-simulation geometries of the projectile are compared in Figure 4, which indicates good general correlation of the deformed profile between test and simulation for the 1 × 2 × 1.2 mm3 element mesh. A more detailed comparison of the ratio of final to original diameters of the Taylor projectile at different distances from the impact end between the simulation and experimental data is shown in Figure 5. In the experiment, some ovalisation of the profile was observed due to the anisotropy of the plate material from which the specimens were machined. Hence, results are presented for both the major and minor axes of the cross-section. For the simulation, no such ovalisation was observed since the material is assumed to be isotropic. Nevertheless, the simulation results agree well with the corresponding test data1 especially near the impact face for this fine mesh density. Hence, both the mesh density and other parameters of the simulation such as the frictional contact conditions were considered suitable for the present class of problems. Figure 4.
Comparison of geometries between test1 and simulation (1 × 2 × 1.2 mm3 element size) after test for an impact velocity of 200 m/s: (a) post-test and (b) post-simulation. Figure 5.
Comparison of test- and simulation-based major and minor side profiles after impact.

sec.title: Comparison of different material models on the deformation of AA7010 alloy projectiles
sec.p:
This section aims to compare the results of the simulations for two different material models. The piecewise linear plasticity model available in LS-DYNA is an elasto-plastic material model with an arbitrary stress versus strain curve and the ability to define arbitrary strain rate dependency. Also, failure based on a plastic strain limit or a minimum time step size can be defined.14 The stress–strain behaviour may be treated as a bilinear stress–strain curve by defining an initial elastic modulus and the plastic tangent modulus. In the present analysis, quasi-static mechanical properties of the AA7010 alloy were obtained from the study of Vili Panov.1 The stress–strain data for different strain rates were computed using the scaling formula given in the study of Raguraman et al.,15 as shown in Figure 6. For the purposes of validation, model parameters such as impact velocity, mass and dimensions of the projectile were kept the same, as described above. Figure 6.
Bi-linear model of true stress–strain behaviour of AA7010 alloy at different strain rates.

The ratio of final to original diameters at different distances from the impact end is compared for the two different material modelling approaches, as shown in Figure 7. It can be seen that a reasonably close agreement between the Johnson–Cook and piecewise linear plasticity-based material model results was found with the Johnson–Cook model, giving a somewhat more accurate prediction of the experimental result of log [D/D0] = 0.08 at the impact end. However, the results for the piecewise linear model was considered sufficiently accurate for this model to be used for the study of the yield drop phenomenon as described in the following section. Figure 7.
Ratio of final to original diameters of projectile for the two different material modelling approaches.

sec.title: Effect of yield drop phenomenon on the deformation of mild steel Taylor projectiles
sec.p: A yield drop usually occurs only for ferritic materials. Hence, mild steel projectiles have been selected to study the effect of yield drop phenomenon rather than the aluminium alloy used for the above validation.

sec.title: Material modelling
sec.p: Although the Johnson–Cook material model is a popular relation to define the strain rate and temperature dependency of a material in numerical simulations, it does not have provision for describing the yield drop phenomenon which is of prime interest in this study. Hence, the alternative piecewise linear plasticity model available in LS-DYNA has been used to study the effects of an upper yield point and the yield drop phenomenon on the deformation behaviour of a steel Taylor projectile. Due to the constraints of the model, thermal softening due to any adiabatic temperature rise was ignored.

The piecewise linear plasticity model is an elasto-plastic material model with a piecewise linear stress versus strain curve and the ability to define arbitrary strain rate dependency. Also, failure based on a plastic strain limit or a minimum time step size can be defined.14 The stress–strain behaviour may be treated as a simple bilinear stress–strain curve by defining an initial elastic modulus and the plastic tangent modulus. In the present analysis, mild steel designated as MS1 in the study of Raguraman et al.16 has been considered as the projectile material. The true stress–strain data at various strain rates obtained from the study of Raguraman et al.16 are used to form the material model, which is reproduced in Figure 8(a). An initial much higher yield stress and subsequent drop in the flow stress back to the standard stress–strain curve were then introduced at various strain rates, as shown in Figure 8(b). Initially, an arbitrary value of upper yield point (i.e. 1000 MPa) at quasi-static strain rates was assumed with the yield drop occurring at a strain of about 0.01. Values for other strain rates were computed using the scaling approach outlined in the study of Raguraman et al.16 A mild steel Taylor projectile of 9.30 mm diameter and 46.5 mm length was considered in the present analysis. In order to investigate the effect of impact velocity, the velocity was varied from 200 to 1000 m/s in steps of 200 m/s. Figure 8.
Material true stress versus true strain data with and without initial yield drop, True stress and strain behaviour of mild steel: (a) without an initial yield drop and (b) with an initial yield drop.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: For further validation of the present numerical scheme, the procedure outlined in ‘Effect of element size on deformation of AA7010 alloy projectiles’ section was repeated to study the effect of element size on the deformation behaviour of mild steel projectiles, impacting against a rigid barrier at an impact velocity of 200 m/s. As before, the projectile was meshed using solid element sizes of 1 × 2 × 1.2 mm3, 1 × 2 × 1.2 mm3, 1 × 3 × 1.2 mm3 and 1 × 4 × 1.2 mm3. The piecewise linear plasticity algorithm shown in Figure 8 was used to represent the stress–strain behaviour of the material, initially without any yield drop condition.

The ratio of final to original diameters of the projectile with distance from the impact end for the different mesh densities is shown in Figure 9. It can be seen that significant differences exist between the different mesh density results. However, the results for the element sizes of 1 × 1 × 1.2 mm3 and 1 × 2 × 1.2 mm3 are again very close to each other, indicating convergence of the numerical solution. Therefore, for reasons of computational efficiency, the element size of 1 × 2 × 1.2 mm3 was considered as a suitable mesh density for the subsequent study of the effect of the yield drop phenomenon. Figure 9.
Effect of element size on the deformation behaviour of mild steel projectiles impacting at a velocity of 200 m/s.

The final simulation profiles with and without yield drop conditions for an impact velocity of 200 m/s are shown in Figure 10(a) and (b), respectively. Although the two cases appear qualitatively quite similar, some detailed differences in the profiles are apparent. The final-to-original diameter ratios against distance from impact end is plotted in Figure 11 for both no yield and yield drop conditions. For the no yield drop condition, the final deformed diameter at the impact face is lower and the deformation profile extends further from the impact end towards the free end. However, in the case of yield drop, the deformed diameter at the impact face is significantly greater and the extent of the plastic deformation along the length of the projectile is much reduced. Thus, there is a significant and measurable effect on the deformation of Taylor projectile due to the introduction of the yield drop phenomenon at this impact speed. Figure 10.
Final deformed profiles for steel projectile with an impact velocity of 200 m/s: (a) without yield drop and (b) with yield drop conditions. Figure 11.
Comparison of original-to-final diameter ratios at different locations from impact end to free end for an impact velocity of 200 m/s.

The deformation profiles at higher impact velocities ranging from 400 to 1000 m/s for different times after impact are shown in Figure 12. A much greater ‘mushrooming’ effect at the impact face is apparent, especially at 1000 m/s. To understand this behaviour more clearly, a comparison of original-to-final diameter ratios at different locations from the impact end for the different impact velocities is shown in Figure 13. It can be seen that the difference in the deformation behaviour between the no yield drop and yield drop conditions becomes far less significant for higher impact velocities. This is because the deformation becomes increasingly dominated by the post-yield response and inertial effects, rather than the initial yield conditions that are influential at the lower impact velocity of 200 m/s. Figure 12.
Deformation profile of steel projectile for different impact velocities. Figure 13.
Comparison of original-to-final diameter ratios at different locations from impact end to free end for an impact velocity of: (a) 400 m/s, (b) 600 m/s and (c) 1000 m/s.

sec.title: Effect of magnitude of initial upper yield point
sec.p:
In order to study the effect of magnitude of the initial upper yield point in the yield drop definition, two different values of initial upper yield point, namely 1000 and 1500 MPa, were considered in the analysis. The numerical scheme outlined earlier was kept unchanged and the simulation was carried out for impact velocities of 200 and 1000 m/s. The ratio of final to original diameters with distance from the impact end for both 1000 and 1500 MPa cases is plotted in Figure 14. It can be seen that there is no significant change in the diameter ratio for these two cases. However, the magnitude of the initial upper yield point may have more significant effect when it is closer in value to the lower yield stress. Figure 14.
Effect of initial upper yield point on the deformation of steel projectile for an impact velocity of: (a) 200 m/s and (b) 1000 m/s.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: A numerical study of the effect of the yield drop phenomenon on the deformation behaviour of Taylor projectiles has been carried out. Good agreement between test and simulation results was found for a trial aluminium projectile with a suitably refined mesh. Having validated the numerical procedure, the effect of the yield drop phenomenon was studied using a simple piecewise linear plasticity model for mild steel which has provision for introducing the yield drop effect and in which temperature effects were ignored. A significant influence of the yield drop phenomenon on the deformation behaviour of the projectile at low impact velocities of the order of 200 m/s was found. However, the effect was far less significant at higher impact velocities (>400 m/s). It is concluded that the yield drop phenomenon may have an important influence on the numerical analysis of high-strain rate deformations and this should be apparent in the final deformed profile of Taylor impact test specimens impacted at moderate impact velocities. The Taylor test may, therefore, be a suitable means of investigating this phenomenon.
